Award.AwardTitle: Titan from Many Angles: 3D Mapping of Titan's Methane and Haze Distributions and Surface Spectra
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this program is to use multiple views of the same surface area on Titan to study its atmosphere. It will allow scientists to determine the three dimensional distribution of methane in Titan's lower atmopshere for the first time. Broader impacts of the work include potential relevance to climate and atmospheric circulation patterns on Earth, and involvement of undergraduates in STEM research.

Titan will be imaged by the Keck Observatory, the Hubble Space Telescope, & VIMS (Visible-Infrared Imaging Spectrometer, an instrument on the Cassini spacecraft) to determine the 3-D distribution of methane and hazes in the lower atmosphere. This research will significantly enhance our understanding of aerosols on Titan, enable the search for spatial variation in CH4 in the lowest scale height of the atmosphere, and permit the search for absorption features on Titan's surface.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal uses Cassini spacecraft observations of Titan - spectra obtained with the VIMS spectrometer - to map the 3D distributions of haze and methane gas in Titan's predominantly nitrogen atmosphere, and to map surface brightnesses in the selected wavelengths where methane does not block photons reflected from the surface. One goal of this project was to look for enhanced methane concentrations downwind of lakes, but VIMS spectra were not sufficiently sensitive to low-level methane to support this goal.

Figure 1 shows an example of surface brightnesses retrieved using VIMS spectra. In this case, we map a region called Polaznik Macula, a dark region and a possible lake or lakebed. Titan's atmosphere only allows views of the surface through a few spectral windows. Even with this picket-fence visibility, it is possible to rule out some surface compositions that one might expect from a lakebed containing evaporites.

The Descent Imager/Spectral Radiometer (DISR) probe measured haze opacities and scattering properties as it descended through Titan's atmosphere. During some Cassini flybys of Titan the VIMS spectrometer observed regions from different elevation angles. In principle, these combined views can help resolve the vertical distribution of haze above that region. On January 28, 2010, Cassini flew by Titan (flyby "T66") and obtained over ten VIMS spectral image cubes of the Polaznik Macula region. Our attempts to fit the VIMS spectra with haze profiles similar to the DISR retrievals have failed: the DISR haze profiles produce model spectra that are significantly brighter than the VIMS observations, but only for observations made at low elevation angles. We are working to quantify how the haze profile from T66 differs from the DISR profile.
